clinical_study.official_title: A Pilot Randomized Human Trial on The Effects of Cocoa on Appetite.

lead_sponsor.agency: Brooklyn College of the City University of New York

clinical_study.source: Brooklyn College of the City University of New York

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether high-flavonoid cocoa can decrease appetite in humans. In addition the study is designed to test epicatechin, a compound found in cocoa and procyanidins, a class of compounds found in cocoa, for their ability to decrease appetite in humans.

detailed_description.textblock: The study is a four-way randomized double-blinded crossover trial with randomization balanced for beverage and lab visit order.

primary_outcome.measure: Appetite as assessed by amount of pizza eaten.
primary_outcome.description: Amount of pizza eaten to be assessed two and one half hours after ingestion of the beverage.

secondary_outcome.measure: Appetite as assessed by a Visual Analog Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Visual Analog Scale assessments to be conducted during the two and one half hours after ingestion of the beverage.

arm_group.description: Low-flavonoid cocoa powder with 0 mg of procyanidins and 0 mg epicatechin per kg of body weight will be consumed as a beverage
Cocoa powder with 3.8 mg procyanidins per kg of body weight and 0.6 mg Epicatechin per kg of body weight will be consumed as a beverage.
Low-flavonoid cocoa powder plus 1 mg epicatechin per kg of body weight will be consumed as a beverage.
Low-flavonoid cocoa powder plus 3.7 mg procyanidins per kg of body weight will be consumed as a beverage.

intervention.description: low-flavonoid cocoa powder with 0 mg of procyanidins and 0 mg epicatechin per kg of body weight will be consumed as a beverage.
High-flavonoid cocoa powder with 3.8 mg procyanidins per kg of body weight and 0.6 mg Epicatechin per kg of body weight will be consumed as a beverage.
Low-flavonoid cocoa powder plus 1 mg epicatechin per kg of body weight will be consumed as a beverage
Low-flavonoid cocoa powder plus 3.7 mg procyanidins per kg of body weight will be consumed as a beverage.
